posts.com:
debian help needed

flashed latest debian iso (bullseye 11.5.0) onto 16GB USB drive using Rufus in "dd" mode with no issues

ran debian-installer, installed debian to 8GB USB drive with an encrypted LVM partition and 1GB swap space

install proceeded w/o issues

upon reboot, PC fails to detect OS, F12 into EFI shows no debian bootloader present

is this an issue with grub or do i need to reflash the USB and try again?

PC model: Dell G5587
AHCI enabled
RAID disabled
Secure Boot disabled
Boot From USB enabled
EFI version 1.11.1

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294910
>is this an issue with grub
yes
>do I have to try again
Maybe. To boot EFI it would need to have created a FAT32 partition with EFI Grub on it, did it do that? Note that you don't want to be making an ESP, that would confuse the computer. Just a FAT32 partition with EFI Grub in \EFI\

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
FTM, only issue i had during install was missing non-free Intel Wifi NIC drivers and debian-installer detecting "UEFI mode enabled", prompting me to either force UEFI or not

I didnt force UEFI and the install proceeded without issue

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294910
>F12 into EFI shows no debian bootloader present
Unless you intend this USB to be permanently installed, this is correct. You'd boot it the way you boot installers, not permanently-installed OSes on fixed disks.

posts.com:
I am trying to port some NesC code from an interface that has a register implementation, to one which doesn't.

Old interface:
async command error_t reg_read(uint16_t slave_addr, uint8_t reg, uint8_t *val);
New interface:
async command error_t read(i2c_flags_t flags, uint16_t addr, uint8_t length, uint8_t* data);

What I don't particularly understand is, where does the 'register' argument go in the new one? How do I tell my slave device that I want to read at this register?

For example, the function:

bool _interrupt_polarity() {
uint8_t int_pol;
call I2CReg.reg_read(41, 0x30, &int_pol);
int_pol = (int_pol >> 4) & 0x1;
return int_pol ? 0 : 1;
}
makes perfect sense to me using the old one - the device is on address 41, and I want to read the value of the register at 0x30. How should I express this using the second interface?

https://github.com/tinyos/tinyos-main/blob/master/tos/interfaces/I2CReg.nc
https://github.com/tinyos/tinyos-main/blob/master/tos/interfaces/I2CPacket.nc

posts.sub: Animated movie about a kid losing his sister in a city
posts.com:
I need help finding an animated movie about a kid losing his sister in a big city. I can give you all the details I can remember.

Plot: A little boy and his sister somehow get lost in a big, trashy city. At some point in the movie, the little boy loses his sister in a huge group of people during what looks like rush hour. The sister is swept away in a big, dramatic scene as they both frantically try to find each other.

The people clear and the boy realizes that his sister is nowhere to be scene. The boy then goes on a journey through the city to find his sister and meets a bunch of weird throwaway characters along the way. I remember one of the characters being a rude hotdog vendor smoking a comically large cigar and ashing in the hotdog water.

Eventually, the kid meets a man in a subway station at night. The boy was startled by how gruff and intimidating the man looked, but was calmed when the man turned away from him and laid down in a pile of newspapers. I remember a sappy, sad orchestral song began to play as the kid realized that the man was homeless.

The two of them talked, had a heart-to-heart, yadda yadda yadda, then the kid revealed that he lost his sister in the city and had been looking for her all day. The homeless man then decides to join the boy on his journey to find his sister.

The two leave the subway and a montage of them meeting more strange, rude and "wacky" characters plays. The montage ends with two of them ending up at the entrance of a dark, "spooky" alleyway. The boy is too scared to go inside the alley, but the homeless man tells the boy something like he's been in lots of alleys like this one, so he's got nothing to worry about.

The two of them walk into the alley. The kid looks really nervous as he hesitantly walks behind the homeless man. A scuttling sound echoing through the alley and makes the kid turn around. When he looks back, the homeless man in gone.

>cont

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A voice says something like "up here, child" and the kid looks up to see a giant spider wearing a black suit, a top hat, and what I remember as four monocles on half of his eyes. The spider asks why the kid is scared, then the kid answers that he lost his friend in the alley.

The spider slowly crawls down from the alley wall and says something like "if he was a friend, why would he leave you hear all alone?" I should also note that the spider had a posh English accent and a deep voice.

The spider starts to sing in a kind of slow, opera-esque voice. These are the lyrics I remember, but not sure how accurate they are after so many years.

"Don't you want a friend? A special kind of friend? I will be there 'till the end. I'm just that kind of friend. I may look a bit scary, perhaps a tad too hairy, but a gentleman's cane I carry. But I understand why you're wary."

The giant spider then weaves a piano from his webs and starts playing an upbeat, jazzy sounding song about how he can be the boy's new friend and how lots of people in the city wouldn't make good friends for the boy.

The musical number was full of visual gags, the one I remember the most was the spider playing the drums, the piano and a saxophone or trumpet all at once. The song starts to pick up in speed, the kid is playfully picked up by the spider and set on his back, and they both start dancing.

The song gets faster and I think the lyrics get more revealing about the spider's intentions, then the spider crawls up the alley wall with the kid still on his back. The music crescendos on a shot of the kid's shocked face and then cuts to a shot of the homeless man stuck in a giant web with webbing covering his mouth.

That's right about the time my little brother would start whining about how the movie was scaring him and that he wanted to turn it off. We had a VCR in the living room, so if you watched something, the whole family did, and I only got to watch maybe 30 minutes of it twice.

>cont

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1295251

My little brother and I would get into fights because I wanted to watch the rest of the movie but he couldn't make it passed the end of the spider's song. I remember the lyrics to the opening of the song to this fucking day because I used to try to scare my brother by singing the lyrics to him whenever our parents weren't around.

We only had the film for a little bit before we had to return it to the library (not sure if many other libraries have DVDs or VHS tapes, but ours back in Sault Ste Marie, Michigan in 2003 did). Once again, I don't remember the name of the movie or when it was made, but the animation style looked like it could've been a late 80's or early 90's movie.

I know it's been a long-ass post, but I really want to find this movie again so I can finish it with my little brother after all these fucking years. If any of you remember this movie, please fucking tell me what it is. Been looking everywhere by searching "spider wearing suit movie," "kids get lost in city movie," and shit like "giant spider musical movie."

Help would be greatly appreciated.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

>contaminating a jury pool
How can you contaminate a jury pool by quoting the law and the constitution? Prosecutors don't like the idea that you know about jury nullification, but it's just a fancy name for the logical consequence of the jury's verdict being de-jure correct. If there could be a "wrong" verdict there'd be no need for a jury because the judge would determine what the correct verdict was and the jury would have to return to the same correct verdict or be in contempt of court. Ergo there can be no such thing as a "wrong verdict", so jury nullification is de-jure legal, and talking about it is merely mentioning true facts about the law.

i think the motivation is like this:
if you are a consumer or a business, you will be less likely to take out a loan (for a house or car, for example) due to a higher borrowing cost. that higher borrowing cost should lead to a drop in demand for goods in general because people are more reluctant to spend, leading to lower prices or at least stabilized prices (the businesses are trying to make the most sales in response to a drop in consumer demand)
this is the ideal situation where inflation is kept on a leash, but if the federal reserve raises the rates too aggressively, no one is spending at all and the country goes into recession

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1295068
>>Don't companies then raise the price to make up for lost sales?
>no, if they set the price too high, no one would buy
They actually lower the price to make up for lost sales. This is a supply/demand graph, which is basically a simplification of the aggregate process of all the consumers "negotiating" with all the producers, mainly through the mechanism of the producers offering products, and the consumers either buying them or not buying them. The "S line" represents the supply side: the further upwards* the price of the thing, the more suppliers will be motivated to produce it, and the more things will be produces. The "D line" represents the demand side: the lower the price of the thing, the more parties are interested in buying it and the more things you can sell. The area above D, the price is too high, and no-one will buy. The area below S, the price is too low, and anyone who sold would lose money**. The only useful quadrant is West/left: this represents the section where there are products being offered for sale and people buying them. If you're somewhere in the left-most quadrant, you can increase your price and people will still buy your products in the same quantity (go up on the graph until you hit the D line), or sell more products at the same price (go right on the graph until you hit the D line), though that price might not actually support the level of capital investment required to create that production (go right on the graph until you hit the S line). The aggregate of all the sellers trying to do that means the market finds the intersection point between S and D, and that is how much stuff is being made and what people are paying for it.

This is of course a massive abstraction, and only really useful for asking questions that can be expressed by moving one of these lines, like "what would happen if there was less consumer demand?".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1295068
If the consumers all have less money, then the D line moves downwards. This removes the rectangular section at the top of the successful transactions quadrant, and
- for any given price there's less demand
- the most efficient price is lower
- at the most efficient price, there's less products being produced and sold


* economics is kinda weird and obtuse, and for some reason puts the dependent quantity on the X axis. I always find this graph a massive counterintuitive headfuck.
** > how come the first X units make money but the rest don't?
The graph represents the entire market in aggregate, so there will be some suppliers who are more efficient and can sell their product for less and still make money, and some who are less and can't

If you only want to game (no machine learning stuff), I would go for the RX 6600 instead.
It goes down to $200 on sale and is ~30% better than the RTX 3050.

The B450 motherboard might give you trouble if the BIOS isn't up-to-date.
You should go for a B550 instead, or else you may need to borrow an older processor to flash a newer BIOS.
Plus you get PCIe 4.0 with the B550 while the B450 is only 3.0.

Consider the Ryzen 5 4500 or 5600 for the CPU.
They're better value than the 5600x.

The RAM is fine, but a non-RGB model with the same speed and CL would be cheaper.

The Corsair RM850x is a great PSU, but unless you're planning to upgrade to more power-hungry CPU/GPU, you should go for a 650W or even 550W model.
That would be cheaper, and PSUs are most efficient around the 50% mark.
Since your system would barely use 250W at full load, it's better to use a lower power PSU.
Just make sure to pick one that's tier A or B on this list (RM850x is tier A):

So I had my old PC shutting down only when playing certain games. These games were usually newer ones, but not necessarily intensive (Valheim, DMCV, apex legends). But playing older games like Dota 2, DMC HD collection, or Minecraft did not shut down my PC at all. The shutdowns were instantly turning off; no error or blue screens. It only happened when playing a game, never when working on my desktop or doing other stuff. I checked event viewer and only saw "the previous shutdown was unexpected". This led to me believing it must be a hardware issue and not a software one, or else a log would show up I thought.

So knowing this, I replaced my PSU, thinking it was going bad, with a 1000w gold cert PSU and it still shut down. I changed my storage to an m.2 drive, I changed my outlet choice, changed my power extender, changed my fans, cleaned out the PC, reinstalled my drivers, reset bios, nothing worked. I came to a point where I just rebuilt the entire PC and did an entire fresh install of windows 11. The only single part now in my PC that is from my old one is my AMD 6900xt GPU. Everything else is completely brand new parts. So I booted up Valheim on my pretty much brand new PC and it shut down in 5 minutes while talking on discord while playing. It is easily replicated too.

So it now comes down to either being the GPU or my apartment is simply haunted. I did try changing the outlets before and just now I tried changing to a completely different room in my apartment with another outlet and it still shut down in the intro to Valheim. I have owned this GPU for about 1.5 years and I have no idea how to check if the GPU is failing, but I never had these shutdowns when I first got it. I don't really remember when these shutdowns started occurring either, maybe a few months ago. Does anyone have any ideas? I don't have any other GPU to test with and I am trying to find an excuse not to spend 1000$ on a GPU.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294754
There are two common reasons for a shutdown like this: overheating, or a power supply that cannot keep up.

Try playing your games a few time with OpenHardwareMonitor or Speccy running in the background. It will show the current temperature of key components (mostly the CPU and GPU are the ones to watch for here). If these get too high, your computer will force stop to avoid damage. If your CPU or GPU go over 75 degrees celcius while playing and then shutdown, I suspect an issue of this sort, which can be fixed by upgrading your cooling (or, often, just vacuuming the accumulated dust and gunk out of your PC).

If it isn't temperature, it's possible your power supply cannot keep up with the power draw used by your GPU when running at full tilt. If your computer uses more power than the PSU can supply, voltage will drop and the computer will also force shutdown. A quick google suggests you want a 750W power supply with the GPU you listed. Do you have that? What power output is your PSU rated for?

You're living in denial, OP.
It's the GPU, it has to be the GPU.
You replaced literally everything but the GPU. Hell, assemble your old stuff into a second computer, and you'll be able to move the failure back and forth by moving the GPU between them.

>>1294934
>A quick google suggests you want a 750W power supply with the GPU you listed. Do you have that?

>>1294754
>I replaced my PSU, thinking it was going bad, with a 1000w gold cert PSU and it still shut down.
There's a possibility OP has a split-rail supply and has configured it dumbly; this is easily tested by looking at the side of it and seeing if it's split-rail or not, and if it is, reading the manual to make sure the CPU 8-pin and every GPU power connector are plugged into different rails. But it probably isn't because split-rail went out of fashion years ago.

You image is vague. Do you want to use a laptop as the display of another PC which uses the keyboard of the laptop and a mouse connected to the laptop?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294135
I doubt it because the connections between the keyboard and screen are on the motherboard and sometimes they are propietary, meaning that if the laptop wasn't really built with that feature in mind, no equipment would be able to do this without having to disassemble your laptop.
However, there are alternatives. You use the desktop as a "server" by streaming the output to your laptop while sending input to it, which is pretty much what you want. The only problem I see is latency. Do you have your PCs in the same network? are the connections with decent speed (aka wired vs wireless, difference in standards Cat4 or 5, or Wifi 4, 5 or 6, etc)?
Lots of factors could affect the latency, but maybe it will be negligible. You won't know until you give it a try.
Research about VNC and/or RDP and similar.
They are ways to do what I am telling you.

posts.com: I'm having booting problems with my SSD. If I reinstall Windows on a new disk, delete the c drive and then clone the old c drive onto it, would it boot like normal? Pic unrelated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294099
Windows is installed in C:\Windows.
So deleting the drive deletes the new install.
And cloning the old drive will give you an unbootable system again.

You'll have to manually move your files from the old install to the new install on the new disk.

>actually I meant the OS doesn't work
If you were on Windows 10, DISM. But you're not, so repair install
>I reinstall Windows on a new disk, delete the c drive and then clone the old c drive onto it, would it boot like normal?
This is an incredibly perverse and complicated way to achieve the same thing as just installing windows to the C drive. So just install windows to the c drive, and it will move all your old stuff to \windows.old\
>Moving the files wouldn't be a problem but my issue are the browsers and its settings.
You probably shouldn't reinstall windows then. Try getting your OS booted in safe mode, then running SFC.

says it's dying. I'm sorry it's bad news, but this is a problem you'll need to confront.

Get a device the same size or larger, ddrescue as much as you can, then chkdsk, dism and then sfc, then startup repair until it hopefully starts. If it won't, at least you can recover most of the files.

posts.com: Bros I fucked up and I put a dent in my friend's truck bumper. I need to either fix it or he's going to take it into a body shop. Can I take it out myself? How much would it cost if he takes it in?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: you can try some heavy suction (i think autoshops use something like a glorified toilet plunger), or pushing it out from behind

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
looks similar to my truck bumper. I did a little digging around and to repair it would take a little work, but the parts should be pretty fucking cheap.

The bumper cover itself is cheap plastic shit that you can re-use. in my case the issue was that the actual metal/steel parts that are the actual bumper was bent. Needless to say they were fucked but it was only a couple pieces that assembly part wasn't too complex. I'd do it myself if I had a helper and the ability to comfortably get under there but I don't.

If you can get it up or at least raised to access that part and get a helper (or probably don't even need one), the parts should only be a couple hundred max and you can do it yourself.

I'm going to also guess any auto body shop would start off at a grand for that.
